job_title: Chief Executive Officer (CEO) in Deland, FL
pros:
AdventHealth DeLand has an incredible team that is committed to to high quality work and has a strong family atmosphere across all units.
Wages and benefits are continually evolving to meet the rapidly shifting healthcare landscape. 
The food is outstanding in our Cafeteria.
cons: Smaller team feel is more personal and while it is mostly a positive, it does mean that team members will know more about you and it isn’t just a place to come and go and disappear in the masses.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Port Orange, FL
pros: Smaller hospital so it feels more like family. Can work extra shifts every week for overtime.  Management is easily approachable, up to and including the CEO. They truly care about the patients'.
cons: Insurance not very good. Expect the RN to be the housekeeper (cleaning/rearranging furniture), CNA (changing diapers/assist patient to the bathroom/bedside commode) and be a gopher (crackers/H2O/coffee) along with normal nursing duties for 6 patients-completed in under an hour and do it every hour the whole shift. Not to mention, try fitting in physician rounding, dress changes, etc (stuff we're supposed to be doing)  Don't mind helping, but all of that every hour and it takes up the whole hour, if not more, and that's not including doing my nursing responsibilities.  It makes for a very hectic, stressful, and gut wrenching shift as your the revolving door with multiple admissions/transfers and discharges while all this goes on.  Expected to answer phone calls from work on your days off if they have a question, as well as read your work emails on your days off.

pros: This hospital has a family atmosphere that truly allows for staff to extend the healing ministry of Christ. There are many opportunities for volunteering and helping within the community those in need. Teams work together and silos are being broken down leading to the best patient care possible through their stay and transition to the next levels of care.
cons: Some departments seem to have high turnover leaving for breaks in communication and increasing the repetitive training needs. This can take its toll on seasoned staff.

pros: Good benefits, but leadership is hypocritical
cons: Florida hospital leadership does not live what they profess. The dictum of extending the healing ministry of Christ is a marketing ploy, rather than religious or ethical principle.  They nothing about patients, staff or families. The CEOs boasts of their income and bonuses, while authorizing .5 cents per annum raises for hard working staff. Whites and family members of the leadership do well.   Number of Minorities in leadership are not reflective of the population. There was a great Chaplain here who really cared, we loved him, they moved him and brought one who never comes to visit patients and their families.

pros: The team work was the best at this hospital.  I enjoyed that patients were happier because the the different disciplines really tried to work together to establish good care.  Each discipline is required to ask if the patient needs anything before they leave the room.  Because every one actually does this, the patients rarely have a laundry list of needs.
cons: There is a lot of communication, which is not exactly a bad thing.  But there are a lot of mandatory meetings.

job_title: RN Charge Nurse in Deland, FL
pros: Everyone knows everyone and is very kind. It is easy to ask questions and your opinion is validated. Like anywhere nursing is hard, but this hospital has very good doctors who partner with the nurses to provide quality patient care.
cons: We are often short staffed and this makes it hard on everyone.

pros: Steady Full time hours, and good benefits.  The best part of working for this hospital system is it's culture.  Administration truly wants our patient's to have a good experience.
cons: Poor pay compared to hospitals under the same company.  You'll get several dollars more per hour if you move across county lines and stay with the same company.

pros: Hard working employees that care about the patients and each other
cons: Out of touch upper management. Very top down driven.

pros: Great working relationships with MD's and Master's level clinicians in the ED.  Multiple opportunities to learn and advance personal knowledge of medical conditions, responses, and methods of treatment.
cons: Limited hours and funding for positions.

pros: Despite goals and expectations are ideally amazing at first.
cons: Their actual transparency and objectivity fell short- Upper management live and rules by paper report from immediate management associates and refuses to listen to those with daily interaction with patients and clients.
